content.statement: proc-029-us-guided-access is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Procedures that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding proc-029-us-guided-access helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of proc-029-us-guided-access include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of proc-029-us-guided-access.

definitions_glossary.common_femoral_artery: Safe zone for percutaneous access, between inguinal ligament and bifurcation
definitions_glossary.out_of_plane: Needle approaches perpendicular to ultrasound beam, appears as bright dot
definitions_glossary.in_plane: Needle approaches parallel to ultrasound beam, entire shaft visible
definitions_glossary.anterior_wall_puncture: Preferred technique, accessing only front wall of artery
definitions_glossary.femoral_head: Bony landmark, CFA should overlay medial third of femoral head

indications: All percutaneous arterial access (recommended as standard of care)
Calcified arteries (to find soft spot for puncture)
contraindications: No sterile ultrasound equipment available (relative - use landmarks)
Emergent access when ultrasound would cause delay (rare)

technique.patient_positioning: Supine, leg slightly abducted, externally rotated, flat on table
anatomic_assessment: Note CFA position over femoral head
Choose optimal puncture site (anterior wall, clear of disease)

puncture_technique.out_of_plane: Transverse view, needle enters from side of probe, appears as bright dot
puncture_technique.in_plane: Longitudinal view, needle enters from end of probe, see entire needle
puncture_technique.angle: 45° entry angle for optimal wire passage

confirmation: Visualize needle tip in vessel lumen

complications.prevention: Single anterior wall puncture, avoid back wall
Confirm puncture below inguinal ligament (CFA, not EIA)

complications.management: Ultrasound-guided compression, thrombin injection, surgical repair

complications.prevention: Identify vein position, avoid low puncture
complications.management: Observation (many close spontaneously), covered stent, surgical repair

evidence.guidelines: Society guidelines recommend routine ultrasound guidance

definition.@value: Technique using real-time ultrasound imaging to guide percutaneous needle puncture of arteries for vascular access

citations.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.

learning_objectives: Describe the technique of ultrasound-guided arterial access
Identify the safe zone for femoral artery puncture using ultrasound
Perform ultrasound-guided CFA access using in-plane or out-of-plane technique
Understand the evidence supporting ultrasound guidance
clinical_pearls: The CFA is your target - confirm you're above the bifurcation with ultrasound
CFA should overlay medial third of femoral head - use this landmark
Anterior wall-only puncture reduces bleeding complications
If you can see calcified plaque, you can steer around it
50-70% reduction in complications - this is the strongest evidence in access technique
